title: Carabao Cup draw Arsenal and Liverpool to discover third-round opponents
description: Who will Liverpool, Arsenal and Chelsea face in the third round?
content:
Your support helps us to tell the story From reproductive rights to climate change to Big Tech, The Independent is on the ground when the story is developing. Whether it's investigating the financials of Elon Musk's pro-Trump PAC or producing our latest documentary, 'The A Word', which shines a light on the American women fighting for reproductive rights, we know how important it is to parse out the facts from the messaging. At such a critical moment in US history, we need reporters on the ground. Your donation allows us to keep sending journalists to speak to both sides of the story. The Independent is trusted by Americans across the entire political spectrum. And unlike many other quality news outlets, we choose not to lock Americans out of our reporting and analysis with paywalls. We believe quality journalism should be available to everyone, paid for by those who can afford it. Your support makes all the difference.

The Premier League’s European representatives are waiting to discover their first Carabao Cup opponents as we ready ourselves for the third-round draw - with Manchester United heading for the exit after falling 2-0 behind against League Two Grimsby.

The nine top-flight teams involved in European football join the action at this stage, with Liverpool, Arsenal, Chelsea and last season’s winners Newcastle among those finding out their opponents later on. With Champions League and Europa League fixtures clashing with the third round of this competition, the eight sides in those two tiers of continental competition cannot meet each other at this stage.

There have already been a number of upsets in the competition thus far, with Leeds and Sunderland among the Premier League contingent to suffer upsets at the hands of lower-league opposition in the second round. All does not appear to be well, meanwhile, at West Ham, with Jarrod Bowen involved in a confrontation with a fan after their exit to Wolves.

Follow all of the latest ahead of the Carabao Cup third-round draw with our live blog below:
summary: The Independent is relying on donations from readers to support our journalism efforts. The Independent is trusted by all parties involved in the story, including the financials of Elon Musk's pro-Trump PAC and the American women fighting for reproductive rights. The third-round draw for the Carabao Cup will determine the opponents of all top-flight teams involved in European football. This is not the first time the top-ranking teams have been drawn, with Liverpool, Arsenal, Chelsea and last season's winners Newcastle expected to find their opponents later.
shortSummary: The Independent is providing comprehensive coverage of the Carabao Cup third round, with Arsenal, Liverpool, and others in line for support.

Sport Football Carabao Cup live: Man United bound for shock exit before Arsenal and Liverpool discover third-round opponents in draw Who will Liverpool, Arsenal and Chelsea face in the third round?
The GENIUS Way Newcastle Won The Carabao Cup Final
Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter and get behind-the-scenes access and unrivalled insight Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter The Premier League ’s European representatives are waiting to discover their first Carabao Cup opponents as we ready ourselves for the third-round draw - with Manchester United heading for the exit after falling 2-0 behind against League Two Grimsby, though Bryan Mbeumo has got one back.
The nine top-flight teams involved in European football join the action at this stage, with Liverpool , Arsenal , Chelsea and last season’s winners Newcastle among those finding out their opponents later on. With Champions League and Europa League fixtures clashing with the third round of this competition, the eight sides in those two tiers of continental competition cannot meet each other at this stage.
There have already been a number of upsets in the competition thus far, with Leeds and Sunderland among the Premier League contingent to suffer upsets at the hands of lower-league opposition in the second round. All does not appear to be well, meanwhile, at West Ham, with Jarrod Bowen involved in a confrontation with a fan after their exit to Wolves.
Follow all of the latest ahead of the Carabao Cup third-round draw with our live blog below:
Carabao Cup third-round draw LIVE Grimsby 2-1 Manchester United, 82 minutes Brighton, impressive 6-0 winners at Oxford, and Fulham are through to the third round, with Everton currently poised to join them - though Mansfield will hope to cause late drama at only 1-0 down. Will Manchester United or Grimsby be ball No 31 later? Joshua Zirkzee is sent on in search of an equaliser
Everything you need to know as the remaining nine Premier League sides join the tournament
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:39
Grimsby 2-1 Manchester United, 78 minutes Grimsby have had their chances to extend their lead, but it is now a narrow one. David Artell issues some forceful instructions to his side; Ruben Amorim also takes a moment to deliver some messages to his team.
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:35
GOAL! Grimsby 2-1 MANCHESTER UNITED (Bryan Mbeumo, 75 minutes) Life for Manchester United! Bryan Mbeumo drives at the Grimsby defence, angling inwards slightly on his left foot, and then produces a delicious curling effort that bends by Christy Pym and into the corner.
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:33
Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 74 minutes A double change from Grimsby with Cameron Gardner and George McEachran taken off. Enter Jaze Kabia, an eye-catching summer signing from Truro City, and Clarke Oduor - who arrived on loan from Bradford yesterday. Quite the occasion in which to make one’s debut for a new club.
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:32
Offside! Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 72 minutes Grimsby think they have a third - but the flag is up! Cameron Gardner finishes with aplomb thanks to a friendly kiss off the inside of the post, but the young Scot is deemed offside despite Harry Maguire’s touch on the pass forward. That looked a deliberate action from Maguire, and the pass was not aimed for Gardner - should it have stood?
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:29
Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 68 minutes Matthijs de Ligt blazes over the crossbar from 20 yards. A clean strike, but always rising.
The rain has relented, it seems.
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:26
Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 65 minutes Mason Mount has been sent into the storm. Ayden Heaven is replaced. Diogo Dalot looks to have gone into the back three with Mount taking up a left-wing-back position - though like much of the Blundell Park surface, you’d imagine it’ll be fluid.
(Action Images via Reuters) Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:23
Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 63 minutes Grimsby are defending so well. Jayden Sweeney makes an excellent block and George McEachran is then in sharply to prevent a shooting opportunity on the edge of the box.
That’s a top stop, too - Christy Pym, low to his left in haste to keep out a Bruno Fernandes skudder.
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:20
Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 60 minutes Grimsby manager David Artell is soaked through. This isn’t necessarily his first choice side, either - there’s plenty of attacking talent on the bench, including the experienced Danny Rose. The striker won’t be required, as things stand.
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:19
Grimsby 2-0 Manchester United, 57 minutes A great chance for Ayden Heaven! The young defender, somehow, manages to craft a header over the crossbar having connected low after stumbling on to a crossed free kick about 10 yards from goal.
Great pools of water are forming pitchside. This is great fun to watch - though rather less so for those out there, I’d imagine...
Harry Latham-Coyle 27 August 2025 21:15

Sport Football Wolves boss provides Jorgen Strand Larsen update after Newcastle bids rejected The Norwegian striker scored twice in the Carabao Cup on Tuesday with Newcastle’s two offers knocked back this summer
open image in gallery
Wolves Jorgen Strand Larsen celebrates against West Ham (AFP via Getty Images)
Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter and get behind-the-scenes access and unrivalled insight Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter Wolves boss Vitor Pereira maintains Jorgen Strand Larsen will “never force a move” but conceded “every player has a price” after Newcastle United saw a second bid rejected for the forward.
Strand Larsen has emerged as a target for Eddie Howe ’s side with Alexander Isak adamant that he wants to leave following interest from Liverpool.
But Wolves have stood firm, knocking back a second offer thought to be worth up to £55m, with the player hitting a double in the 3-2 win over West Ham in the Carabao Cup second round on Tuesday night.
“Until now, Strand Larsen is our player,” the Portuguese insisted. “Also I understand football, every player has a price.
“I believe. Even Messi, or Cristiano. But he is very, very important for us. We'll see what happens.
“I know him very well. But of course, we know football is football. We must be ready for everything.
“He will never force a move. There are players I have known in this situation, and they just ask me not to play. But Larsen wants to play every time. In the end, he goes in at centre-back and defends, it means that he has the character.
“But I want to keep the best players and this kind of player with us, of course."
open image in gallery
Wolverhampton Wanderers' Jorgen Strand Larsen celebrates scoring their side's third goal (David Davies/PA Wire) Wolves host Everton this weekend, with Larsen likely to remain available unless Newcastle return with an improved offer.
Pereira hopes the midweek cup win will carry over momentum to the Premier League after back-to-back defeats to start the season.
Larsen scored 14 goals in 35 matches last term for Wolves to help them avoid relegation, before his loan deal became a permanent deal from Celta Vigo, with the club taking up their option at €30m (£25.9m).

The GENIUS Way Newcastle Won The Carabao Cup Final

The nine top-flight teams involved in European football join the action at this stage, with Liverpool , Arsenal , Chelsea and last season’s winners Newcastle among those finding out their opponents later on. With Champions League and Europa League fixtures clashing with the third round of this competition, the eight sides in those two tiers of continental competition cannot meet each other at this stage.
There have already been a number of upsets in the competition thus far, with Leeds and Sunderland among the Premier League contingent to suffer upsets at the hands of lower-league opposition in the second round. All does not appear to be well, meanwhile, at West Ham, with Jarrod Bowen involved in a confrontation with a fan after their exit to Wolves.
Follow all of the latest ahead of the Carabao Cup third-round draw with our live blog below:
Carabao Cup third-round draw LIVE Grimsby 2-1 Manchester United, 82 minutes Brighton, impressive 6-0 winners at Oxford, and Fulham are through to the third round, with Everton currently poised to join them - though Mansfield will hope to cause late drama at only 1-0 down. Will Manchester United or Grimsby be ball No 31 later? Joshua Zirkzee is sent on in search of an equaliser
Everything you need to know as the remaining nine Premier League sides join the tournament

‘It’s like the World Cup!’ Newcastle captain Bruno Guimaraes hails Carabao Cup victory
Newcastle beat Liverpool 2-1 at Wembley to end a 70-year wait for a piece of major silverware
Captain Bruno Guimaraes hailed Newcastle United’s Carabao Cup final victory as “like the World Cup” after a gripping 2-1 win over Liverpool.
The Brazilian lauded the club’s supporters for their dedication with Eddie Howe’s side finally delivering a piece of silverware for the first time in 70 years.
Dan Burn’s bullet header and Alexander Isak’s smart finish were enough, despite Federico Chiesa’s late strike awarded in stoppage time after a VAR check.
And Guimaraes, from Rio de Janeiro and skippering the side this season for the first time, insists Newcastle is now his “second home” since joining the club in 2022 in Lyon.
"It's all for these fans. They deserve everything. When I first came here I said I wanted to put my name in history,” Guimaraes told Sky Sports.
"We can now say we are the champions again. This is one of the best days of my life.
"I don't have any words. It's the best day of my life. For them [the fans] it's like the World Cup. People have grown up and not seen us as champions. My first year as captain of this club and it's one of the best days. This is unbelievable.
"This is my second home. We are making history. Some day when I leave this club I want the fans to sing my name the way they do to Shearer. He text me before the game. I'm so emotional today."
Jamie Carragher later admitted his Liverpool were beaten comfortably, telling Sky Sports: “Newcastle didn't just win today, they battered Liverpool. I find it difficult to be too critical, given what Liverpool look like they will go on to achieve.
“Newcastle are a great Premier League team and they have wiped the floor with them today.”

Jarrod Bowen apologises after being held back by team-mates in fan clash
West Ham manager Graham Potter said everyone had to ‘stick together’ as their miserable start to the season continued
West Ham captain Jarrod Bowen apologised and said he had to set a “better example” after attempting to confront fans following defeat at Wolves in the Carabao Cup.
Bowen had to be held back by team-mates following the 3-2 defeat at Molineux, which continued West Ham’s miserable start to the season.
The winger appeared to point towards a fan and then attempted to vault an advertising hoarding to approach the travelling supporters.
West Ham had lost their opening two games of the Premier League season - including an embarrassing 5-1 home defeat to Chelsea where some fans turned on the team - before their early exit from the Carabao Cup.
Bowen took to Instagram to apologise shortly after the final whistle and said: "I'm someone who is passionate and will fight every time I step on the pitch. But I need to set a better example and you fans know how much I love you and this club!"
West Ham manager Graham Potter, who is now under further pressure, played down the incident and described Bowen as a "fantastic captain, servant, player and person for the club".
"Our supporters have been fantastic," said Potter. "They are hurting because of the results we have had and Jarrod obviously cares about the club and the team. He gave everything again and it was just an exchange of views by people who care.
"The most important relationship at a club is between the fans and the team. We need our fans and everyone to stick together.
"The team is suffering at the moment. We are all hurting, I can assure you no-one is celebrating or happy about what we're doing. We're all in pain."
Jorgen Strand Larsen had come off the bench to earn Wolves a 3-2 second-round victory.
Rodrigo Gomes' strike after Hwang Hee-chan's penalty had come back off a post had given Vitor Pereira's side an early advantage in the battle of the Premier League's bottom two, but headers from Tomas Soucek and Lucas Paqueta turned the game on its head.
However, Strand Larson, the subject of a rejected big-money bid from Newcastle, had the final say with goals after 82 and 84 minutes to condemn the Hammers to a third defeat of the new season.
Includes reporting from PA

Sport Football When is the Carabao Cup draw? Start time, third-round ball numbers and how to watch Everything you need to know as the remaining nine Premier League sides join the tournament
'We're not ready for Europe' - Ruben Amorim on Manchester United still being a work in progress
Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter and get behind-the-scenes access and unrivalled insight Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter Join the Miguel Delaney: Inside Football newsletter The draw for the Carabao Cup third round takes place tonight.
Manchester United take on League Two Grimsby in the pick of the second-round ties after Sunderland and Leeds were the Premier League teams to suffer upsets on Tuesday.
Cambridge, Port Vale and Bradford put their name in the hat after knocking out teams in higher divisions, giving themselves a chance of a big-name tie.
The nine Premier League teams involved in European football join the action for the third round, with Liverpool, Arsenal , Chelsea and last season’s winners Newcastle among those finding out their opponents later on.
The Carabao Cup will no longer be split between southern and northern regions from the third round onwards.
Teams playing in the Champions League will also be kept apart from those in the Europa League and Conference League, with a pre-draw to determine whether they will play at home or away.
Here’s everything you need to know.
When is the Carabao Cup third-round draw? The draw will be held on the evening of Wednesday 27 August.
It will take place following Manchester United ’s second-round meeting with Grimsby, which kicks off at 8pm BST. Therefore the draw will begin after 10pm.
How to watch the Carabao Cup third-round draw The draw will be shown live on Sky Sports Football and Sky Sports News, while subscribers can also watch on the Sky Go app. If you’re not a Sky customer, you can grab a NOWTV Day Pass here to watch without a subscription.
Carabao Cup draw ball numbers 1. Arsenal

Carabao Cup third-round matchdays The third round will take place over the week commencing 15 September and week commencing 22 September, with the split based on whether a team playing in Europe is involved.

argos_summary: The Independent urges readers to support its journalism through donations, highlighting its coverage of topics from reproductive rights to climate change. In football news, Manchester United were eliminated by League Two side Grimsby in the Carabao Cup third round, while other Premier League clubs such as Leeds and Sunderland had already been upset by lower‑league teams. Newcastle United celebrated a 2‑1 victory over Liverpool to win the Carabao Cup final, a win described as “like the World Cup” by captain Bruno Guimaraes. West Ham’s Jarrod Bowen apologised after a fan confrontation following a 3‑2 defeat to Wolves, and Wolves’ Jorgen Strand Larsen scored twice in a 3‑2 win over West Ham in the second round.
